title: Phonetically-rich paragraph
reason: Contains diverse phonemes and varied prosody; good for baseline controlled read speech.
instruction: Read this paragraph naturally in a steady voice, aiming for about one minute.
content: The quick brown fox jumped easily over the lazy dog and then paused to listen. Small children played on the streets while a bicycle bell chimed. Across the market, vendors shouted offers of fresh fruit and coffee, and an old man in a blue jacket whistled an unfamiliar tune. She carried a worn leather satchel filled with letters, a brass key, and a folded map that hinted at distant places she had yet to see. Please tell me where the road leads next.

title: Harvard-style short sentences
reason: Covers a wide range of phonemes and natural sentence boundaries; ensures phonetic variety.
instruction: Read each sentence clearly and naturally with short pauses between them.
content: The sky above the port was the color of television, tuned to a dead channel.
A large, dark field of wheat rolled down the hill in waves.
The early bird may get the worm, but the second mouse gets the cheese.
A sudden gust made the papers fly across the lawn.
He opened the small wooden box and found nothing but a single key.
The museum closes at six, but tonight there’s a late concert.
She wore a hat with a bright red feather stuck in the brim.
The children chased the kite until it snapped and drifted away.
A cup of coffee can change a slow morning into a busy one.
They decided to meet at the old bridge at noon.

title: Numbers, addresses, structured phrases
reason: Captures digits, alphanumerics, dates, and formal phrases — useful for modeling precise articulation.
instruction: Read the items clearly in one continuous take with small pauses between them.
content: Phone number: six one seven — five five five — zero one two three.
Dates: January twenty-first, nineteen ninety-seven; August third, two thousand five.
Time: seven thirty a.m., nine fifteen p.m., midnight.
Address: 482 Willow Street, Apartment 3B, Springfield.
Code sample: A7B-3C9, license plate ZQK-482, tracking number 1Z9999W99999999999.
Bank-style: transfer two hundred and fifty dollars to account ending nine eight seven six.

title: Ad-lib prompts
reason: Encourages spontaneous speech with natural prosody, fillers, and variable intonation.
instruction: Do not read these prompts. Instead, answer each prompt aloud in your own words for 8–12 seconds.
content: Describe your favorite meal — what is it, how it’s made, and why you like it.
Tell a short story about a memorable trip or day out.
Explain how to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich step by step.
Describe a movie or book you love and why others should see or read it.
Talk about a recent funny or awkward moment that happened to you.
Describe your daily commute — sights, sounds, and what you think about.

title: Prosody variation (same paragraph, different styles)
reason: Captures the same lexical content under different emotional tones; improves robustness to expressive variation.
instruction: Read the following paragraph three times: once neutral, once happy/energetic, and once tired/slow.
content: On a rainy morning she stood by the window and watched the droplets race each other down the glass. The city hummed quietly, and somewhere a distant bus wheezed past. She sipped her coffee slowly as if trying to remember the last time she had felt completely unhurried.
